qas.question: To what has the Central Board of Education of India relegated Sanskrit?
Where has the Education Board ranked Sanskrit as a language option?
What grades in Indian schools have an option for Sanskrit study?
In what language states is Sanskrit considered an option?
In what other type of schools is Sanskrit also taught?
What board refused to see Sanskrit as an alternative option?
What is the only India board of education?
What language is the state official language of India?
In which grades is learning Sanskrit required?
Traditional gurukulas no longer teach what language?

context: <b5_0>The CBSE<b5_0/> (<b6_0>Central Board of Secondary Education<b6_0/>) of India, along with several other state education boards, has made <b7_0>Sanskrit<b7_0/> an <a0_0>alternative option<a0_0/> to the state's own official language as a <a1_0>second or third<a1_0/> language choice in the schools it governs. In such schools, learning Sanskrit is an option for <b8_0>grades <a2_0>5 to 8<b8_0/><a2_0/> (Classes V to VIII). This is true of most schools affiliated with the ICSE board, especially in those states where the official language is <a3_0><b9_0>Hindi<b9_0/><a3_0/>. Sanskrit is also taught in traditional <a4_0>gurukulas<a4_0/> throughout India.
